name: NewYorker
text: .@hels recommends edible (and edible-adjacent) holiday gifts, from many varieties of banana to spaghetti bedsheets. https://t.co/HOnnUqju2b

name: NewYorker
text: “The Chinese lockdown was more intense than almost anywhere else in the world,” writes Peter Hessler, who teaches at Sichuan University. It wasn’t unheard-of for a door to be sealed shut during contact-tracing if a family was suspected of exposure. https://t.co/LV6Yus8yMW

name: NewYorker
text: In theory, the approval of two vaccines for the coronavirus should have made reaching a deal on a new spending deal easier. The barrier is raw partisan politics on the part of the G.O.P., @JohnCassidy writes. https://t.co/EujVqzlukP

name: NewYorker
text: In our Weekend Crossword, seven letters: Island ceded to France by Genoa in 1768. https://t.co/5IoBTozEqy

name: NewYorker
text: Has a desire to protect children put their long-term well-being at stake? “My biggest concern is that we’re going to lose these kids,” one teacher says. “They might never come back.” https://t.co/vpRRRlBrZx

name: NewYorker
text: “We wanted her ruined, helpless, destroyed. Because Silvia always knew more”: Fiction by Mariana Enriquez. https://t.co/kBL85B2MGG

name: NewYorker
text: “Back to square 1 but more motivated than ever!” https://t.co/QpOjPfzXRL

text: In which Jack Handey asks a former colleague, the Antichrist, for a favor. https://t.co/3dmPA9YX2H

name: NewYorker
text: “I often have trouble making sense of an experience until I’ve laboriously written it down, or turned it into fiction.” An interview with Paul Theroux. https://t.co/i59BsaLRaD

name: NewYorker
text: Who wouldn’t love 2.75 pounds of loose pillow mints or 3.5 metres of slender salami, wrapped around a wooden spindle? https://t.co/EJyc1F4gO9

name: NewYorker
text: People experience genuine pleasure—a rush of dopamine—when processing information that supports their beliefs. “It feels good to ‘stick to our guns’ even if we are wrong,” researchers say. https://t.co/EHWXZkMEo7

name: NewYorker
text: “Right from the beginning, I’ve always gone to stories when I feel that I can tell them in a special way, that they’re mine, that they won’t let me go.” An interview with the filmmaker @MiraPagliNair. https://t.co/Rw59H9TNtY

name: NewYorker
text: Slack was designed to optimize the haphazard approach to work that e-mail initiated. The problem, Cal Newport writes, is that no one stopped to ask if it made sense to optimize this style of work in the first place. https://t.co/qVypJvi9uF

name: NewYorker
text: Read @praddenkeefe’s 2017 reporting on how Purdue Pharma’s ruthless marketing of OxyContin generated billions of dollars—and millions of addicts. https://t.co/9KYvWElQzb

name: NewYorker
text: A scene from Oliver Hirschbiegel’s 2004 film “Downfall,” of Hitler’s final days, has spawned a thousand YouTube parodies. But it is based, in part, on problematic sources. https://t.co/93l7egdBkE

name: NewYorker
text: Pfizer and Moderna developed coronavirus vaccines with extremely high efficacy rates in less than four months—an unprecedented pace. How did it happen, and what comes next? https://t.co/uZvIQUJ5T7

name: NewYorker
text: Protests against police violence took place around the world this year. In Nigeria, they might lead to the undoing of a notoriously lawless and brutal police unit. Listen here, on #NewYorkerRadio. https://t.co/YWu0CYGgmP

name: NewYorker
text:
The 36 best movies of the year, according to New Yorker film critic @tnyfrontrow.
 https://t.co/7LKaH0aQYx

name: NewYorker
text: “I’ve been in here for 17 years,” Christopher Fausto Cabrera wrote in one of his letters to the photographer Alec Soth. “I know that none of this is justice. This system creates more problems and solves nothing.” https://t.co/DtNPeRDc6Z

name: NewYorker
text: The members of Veterans for Responsible Leadership believe that President Trump threatens the very principles they risked their lives defending—and so they’ve organized to help defeat him. https://t.co/5V23eRhqTe

name: NewYorker
text: RT @michaelluo: As Christians prepare anew to celebrate the Incarnation, I revisit early church history as a reminder of the devotion to the common good Jesus can inspire and lament how this has been, to a distressing degree, an ignominious year for the church in America. https://t.co/3uUAAwy5MG

name: NewYorker
text: “The Fountain of Youth,” which is streaming on YouTube, is as artistically original for television as “Citizen Kane” was for the movies, @tnyfrontrow writes. https://t.co/QWqmTAFoKC

name: NewYorker
text: As the awful year of 2020 draws to a close, at least one small group of people will look back on it as a very prosperous one: America’s billionaires. https://t.co/ye2WgCntS6

name: NewYorker
text: RT @hels: ICYMI I wrote a holiday gift guide with everything you need to know about rare bananas, diner-style pillow mints, and the connection between hip vintage French wine jugs and the 1953 federal execution of the Rosenbergs https://t.co/OGvAR6kkyE

name: NewYorker
text: COVID-19 has held a mirror to the Christian church, just as the epidemics of antiquity did—but today’s reflection is, to a distressing degree, an ignominious one. https://t.co/yCEmk5dLO8

name: NewYorker
text: RT @erinoverbey: Sunday reading from @NewYorker archive: this week, we're highlighting pieces on the extraordinary impact of Black Lives Matter & the racial-justice movement of 2020—w/stories by @zzpacker, @KeeangaYamahtta, @ProfessorEA, Hilton Als +more. #NewYorkerArchive https://t.co/goIiQjwMhg
